facts.text: Appeal by Special Leave from the judgment and order dated January 24, 1969 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 942 of 1968.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by Special Leave from the judgment and order dated January 24, 1969 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 942 of 1968. S. R. Chari, R. Nagaratnam, S. K. Mehta, K. L. Mehta and K. R. Nagaraja, for the appella

facts.text: Appellant convicted by the Special Judge, Jabalpur under s. 5(1)(d) read with s. 5(2) of the Prevention of Corruption Act to one year's rigorous imprisonment and a fine of Rs. 1000.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant who was Professor and Head of the Department of Pharmacology and Therapeutics in the Medical College, Jabalpur, has been convicted by the Special Judge, Jabalpur under s. 5 1  d  read with s. 5 2  of the Prevention of Corruption Act to one years rigorous imprisonments and a fine of Rs. 1 000 and in default to undergo rigorous imprisonment for three months.

facts.text: Appellant further convicted under ss. 409 and 420 I.P.C. and awarded six months rigorous imprisonment for each.

anchor.surface_text: He was further convicted of offence 13-L736Sup CI/72 under ss. 409 and 420 I.P.C. and was awarded sentences of six months rigorous imprisonment in respect of each of them. All the sentences were directed to run concurrently.

facts.text: Appeal against conviction and sentence to the High Court of Madhya Pradesh was dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: All the sentences were directed to run concurrently. An appeal against this conviction and sentence to the High Court of Madhya Pradesh was dismissed. This appeal is by special leave.

facts.text: Appellant employed in Medical College, Jabalpur, accepted grant-in-aid with permission of Government of Madhya Pradesh on December 20, 1962 for research project 'Study of Manganese in Health and Disease by Neutron Activation Analysis'.

anchor.surface_text: Shortly stated the case of the prosecution is that the appellant who was employed in the Medical College, Jabalpur, with the permission of the Government of Madhya Pradesh given on December 20, 1962, accepted a grant-in-aid for carrying out a research project entitled Study of Manganese in Health and Disease by Neutron Activation Analysis.

facts.text: Research project in collaboration with Atomic Energy Commission for three years 1963-64, 1964-65, 1965-66. Appellant began research in July 1963.

anchor.surface_text: This Research Project was to be carried on in collaboration with the Atomic Energy Commission of the Government of India for three years 1963-64, 1964-65 and 1965-66. The appellant began his research work in July 1963 and sometime thereafter on September 30, 1964,

facts.text: On September 30, 1964, Stadler Still Double Distillation Apparatus purchased from Messrs S. K. Biswas Company of Calcutta for Rs. 450.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant began his research work in July 1963 and sometime thereafter on September 30, 1964, an instrument for distillation of water known as the Stadler Still Double Distillation Apparatus was purchased from Messrs S. K. Biswas Company of Calcutta a firm of scientific instruments manufacturers and dealers of Calcutta, for Rs. 450.

facts.text: On April 11, 1964, ICMR entrusted appellant with research project on Effect of Hypoxia and Decompression on Body Temperature.

anchor.surface_text: On April 11, 1964, the Indian Council of Medical Research known as the 1.C.M.R. entrusted him with the research project on Effect of Hypoxia and Decompression on Body Temperature as function of Adaptation to Hypoxia at various altitude.

facts.text: Appellant placed order with Messrs Goverdhandas Desai Private Ltd., Bombay on February 20, 1965 for double distillation apparatus for Rs. 890.

anchor.surface_text: For this project the appellant wanted to purchase another double distillation apparatus and after inquiry from several firms placed an order with Messrs Goverdhandas Desai Private Ltd. Bombay  hereinafter called Messrs Goverdhandas  as per Ext. P-5 dated February 20, 1965 for a double distillation appara- tus, horizontal type, Double Stage, capacity 10 litres, pyrex glass for Rs. 890

facts.text: Messrs Goverdhandas sent wire and advance bills on March 3, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: Messrs Goverdhandas sent wire Ext. P-6 and the advance bills Exts. P-8, P-9, and P-10 to the appellant on March 3, 1965. This apparatus was entered in the stock register of the 1.C.M.R. Hypoxia Enquiry as per Ext. P-44

facts.text: Appellant on leave from February 9, 1965 to March 20, 1965 due to heart trouble.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned at this stage that the appellant was on leave from February 9, 1965 to March 20, 1965 because of heart trouble and the inquiry and the order were placed during that period.

facts.text: Draft in favour of Messrs Goverdhandas issued by Accounts Officer, ICMR, received by appellant on April 12, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: A draft in favour of Messrs Goverdhandas was subsequently issued by the Accounts Officer, 1.C.M.R. and was received by the appellant on April 12, 1965.

facts.text: Order cancelled by letter Ext. P-17 dated April 24, 1965 as firm could not supply as per specifications.

anchor.surface_text: As the firm was not able to supply the apparatus as per the specifications the order was cancelled by letter Ext. P-17 dated April 24, 1965.

facts.text: Appellant in Bombay between May 15, 1965 and May 25, 1965 for medical check-up.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the appellant was in Bombay between May 15, 1965 and May 25, 1965 where he had gone for a medical check-up and was staying in the M.L.As. Rest House.

facts.text: On May 17, 1965, appellant met Mr. Patel of Messrs Goverdhandas, handed over draft, received bearer cheque, obtained receipt Ext. P-24.

anchor.surface_text: On May 17, 1965, he met Mr. Patel a Director of Messrs Goverdhandas and asked him to receive the draft and give him a cheque in order to enable him to purchase the apparatus he wanted from the Bombay market. This was agreed to, and accordingly the draft was handed over to Mr. Patel and a receipt Ext. P-24 was obtained from him on behalf of Messrs Goverdhandas.

facts.text: Appellant telephoned Rasiklal Shah (D.W.3) on May 17, 1965, enquired about distillation plant, later Dsouza brought apparatus costing Rs. 989.35, paid and obtained receipt.

anchor.surface_text: On the same day the appellant telephoned to one Rasiklal Shah a partner of the Scientific Sales Syndicate D.W. 3 and enquired whether he could supply the distillation plant as per the specifications given by him. ... According to the appellant on the same day the man sent by Rasiklal Shah is said to have brought the apparatus the cost of which was Rs. 989.35. The appellant paid the money, obtained a receipt and brought it to Jabalpur.

facts.text: Prosecution alleges appellant did not buy another apparatus but used the 1964 one for the ICMR project, misappropriating the draft amount.

anchor.surface_text: The crucial question in this case is whether the accused as alleged by the prosecution did not buy another apparatus for which he had received a draft from the I.C.R. But in fact has been carrying on the work with the distillation apparatus purchased from Messrs S. K. Biswas Company in September 1964, for the project for which he was receiving a grant-in-aid from the Atomic Energy Commission of the Government of India, by pretending that it is the apparatus which he had purchased in Bombay.

facts.text: Double distillation apparatus purchased from S.K. Biswas on September 30, 1964, entries made in stock register of Atomic Energy Commission project. (undisputed)

anchor.surface_text: There are in this case certain undisputed facts which are- That a double distillation apparatus was purchased for the project of the Atomic Energy Commission from Messrs S. Biswas Company on September 30, 1964, and in respect of which entries were made in the stock register of the Atomic Energy Commission.

facts.text: Demand draft for Rs. 969.10 received by appellant on April 12, 1965. (undisputed)

anchor.surface_text: The demand draft was received by the appellant on April 12, 1965. Chokasey P.W. 21 made entries in the stock register of the 1.C.M.R. that the apparatus was received as soon as the Us were received and submitted for payment.

facts.text: Appellant handed over demand draft to Mr. Patel on May 17, 1965 and obtained bearer cheque. (undisputed)

anchor.surface_text: That the appellant went to Bombay on May 17, 1965 and handed over the demand draft issued by the I.C.M.R. in favour of Messrs Goverdhandas to Mr. Patel and obtained a receipt from him. The appellant also obtained from Messrs Goverdhandas a bearer cheque for the same amount for which he gave a receipt to Mr. Patel and cashed the cheque.

facts.text: First Information Report dated August 12, 1966.

anchor.surface_text: It appears from the first information report Ext. P-46 dated August 12, 1966, that during the course of investigation on information received through a source Shri Shyam Biharilal Shrivastava,

facts.text: Supreme Court allows the appeal, sets aside convictions and sentences.

anchor.surface_text: We have no hesitation in holding that the accused is innocent. The appeal is allowed and the convictions and sentences in respect of the several offences are set aside. The bail bond will be cancelled.

facts.text: No firm by the name of M.B. Corporation from which appellant purchased apparatus. (prosecution claim)

anchor.surface_text: the prosecution seeks to establish the case against the appellant by showing- 1  that there is no firm by the name of M.B. Corporation from which the appellant is said to have purchased the apparatus on May 17, 1965

facts.text: Distillation apparatus purchased in September 1964 shown as broken on February 1, 1965 and written off fraudulently. (prosecution allegation)

anchor.surface_text: that the apparatus purchased in September 1964 which had been shown as broken on February 1, 1965 and written off has been in fact not broken but has been entered as such in the registers fraudulently.

facts.text: Appellant produced copy of receipt and letter from Rasiklal Shah to investigating officer before FIR.

anchor.surface_text: Nor did the prosecution mention either the fact that the appellant had obtained a receipt from Messrs Goverdhandas for the demand draft handed over to them or that he had given a receipt for the bearer cheque obtained in exchange by him from Messrs Goverdhandas. There was also no mention in the said document that the appellant had handed over a copy of the receipt for payment of Rs. 989-35 for the purchase of the other apparatus on May 17, 1965, to the investigating officer

K. Biswas Company in September 1964 by pretending it was the one purchased in Bombay thereby misappropriating the amount

Biswas Company in September 1964, for the project for which he was receiving a grant-in-aid from the Atomic Energy Commission of the Government of India, by pretending that it is the apparatus which he had purchased in Bombay.

issues.text: Whether the amount received back by the appellant from Messrs Goverdhandas Desai of Bombay was utilised or not by him in purchasing the apparatus as stated by him

arguments.claim: Prosecution witnesses unable to identify Article A as 1964 apparatus.

anchor.surface_text: Even the High Court, after considering the evidence of Dr. Rajkumar Gupta, P.W. 15... observed that all these witnesses have admitted that they are unable- to identify the double distillation apparatus from another apparatus of the same quality and same markings.

arguments.claim: There was another double distillation apparatus besides the 1964 one.

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand there is the evidence of A. S. Venkatsubbarao P-W. l6 which clearly indicates that there was another double distillation apparatus apart from Article A, the one, purchased in, September 1964.

arguments.claim: Different costs and capacities suggest different apparatuses.

anchor.surface_text: It is seen that the apparatus which was purchased in September 1964 though it was said to be a double distillation apparatus it cost only Rs. 486-62 but a similar distillation apparatus said to have been purchased in May 1965 by the appellant cost Rs. 969-10.

arguments.claim: Rasiklal Shah's letter corroborates purchase.

anchor.surface_text: The letter which is an important piece of evidence is as follows Sub Standler Quickfit type Double Distillation extra strong Pyres SKB. We refer to your telephonic talk...

arguments.claim: Lower courts wrongly placed burden on accused to prove purchase.

arguments.claim: Defense witnesses reliable: Dr. Barat, Hamidullah Khan, Rasiklal Shah.

anchor.surface_text: This evidence has been summarily rejected, and, in our view, without any comment reasons. Dr. Barat D.W. 1 says that he was the one who had started the research...

arguments.claim: Drawing draft before supply is mere irregularity, not criminal intent.

anchor.surface_text: No doubt in this case the prosecution has established that the appellant has drawn a bill and obtained a draft for Rs. 969-10 before the apparatus was supplied. But this is an irregularity and does not show that he had no intention of purchasing the apparatus or to misappropriate the money.

arguments.claim: Appellant innocent; convictions set aside.

anchor.surface_text: We have no hesitation in holding that the accused is innocent. The appeal is allowed and the convictions and sentences in respect of the several offences are set aside. The bail bond will be cancelled.

holdings.text: The onus of proving all the ingredients of an offence is always upon the prosecution and at no stage does it shift to the accused.

anchor.surface_text: In our view, the onus of proving all the ingredients of an offence is always upon the prosecution and at no stage does it shift to the accused. It is not part of the prosecution duty to somehow hook the crook.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lower courts erred by requiring accused to prove purchase; prosecution bears full burden regardless of defence plausibility.

holdings.text: Even in cases where the defence of the accused does not appear to be credible or is palpably false that burden does not become any the less.

anchor.surface_text: Even in cases where the defence of the accused does not appear to be credible or is palpably false that burden does not become any the less.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Burden remains unchanged even if accused's story seems implausible; prosecution must still prove case beyond doubt.

holdings.text: Where the onus shifts to the accused, and the evidence on his behalf probabilises the plea he will be entitled to the benefit of reasonable doubt.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accused's probabilising evidence triggers benefit of doubt even under shifted onus; lower standard than prosecution's proof.

holdings.text: Once these facts had come to the knowledge of the investigating officer, it was his duty to have placed them before the Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Exculpatory material known to police must be disclosed; non-disclosure undermines prosecution.

holdings.text: The accused did purchase the double distillation apparatus in Bombay on May 17, 1965 using the funds from the draft, and did not misappropriate them by using the 1964 apparatus for the ICMR project.

anchor.surface_text: The crucial question in this case is whether the accused as alleged by the prosecution did not buy another apparatus for which he had received a draft from the I.C.R. But in fact has been carrying on the work with the distillation apparatus purchased from Messrs S. K. Biswas Company in September 1964...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prosecution failed to prove beyond doubt; defence evidence (receipts, witnesses, letter from Rasiklal Shah) probabilises purchase; apparatuses differ in cost/capacity; no identity proven.

holdings.text: The amount received back by the appellant from Messrs Goverdhandas Desai of Bombay was utilised by him in purchasing the apparatus.

anchor.surface_text: Thus, the short, question that fell for determination by the Special Judge was whether the amount received back by the appellant from Messrs Goverdhandas Desai of Bombay was utilised or not by him in purchasing the apparatus as stated by him...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Defence probabilises utilisation via receipts, Shah's letter, excess payment; prosecution evidence unreliable (biased witnesses, non-identification).

holdings.text: Drawing advance draft before supply is a mere administrative irregularity, not evidence of criminal intent or misappropriation.

anchor.surface_text: No doubt in this case the prosecution has established that the appellant has drawn a bill and obtained a draft for Rs. 969-10 before the apparatus was supplied. But this is an irregularity and does not show that he had no intention of purchasing the apparatus or to misappropriate the money.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural lapse common in academic settings without staff; no proof of dishonest intent; purchase occurred.

holdings.text: The accused is innocent; convictions and sentences under Prevention of Corruption Act s.5(1)(d)/5(2), IPC ss.409/420 set aside.

anchor.surface_text: We have no hesitation in holding that the accused is innocent. The appeal is allowed and the convictions and sentences in respect of the several offences are set aside. The bail bond will be cancelled.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prosecution case not proved beyond reasonable doubt; defence plea substantiated; benefit of doubt.

holdings.text: Absence of firm M.B. Corporation does not prove guilt as appellant not responsible for spurious bill if given unknowingly.
